text: the roots how I got over whoa my needle
drops Anthony Fantan oh here internets
busiest music nerd going to do an album
review here creaky chair and I wanted to
tell you before I do that it's a remix
Wednesday on the needle drop com if
you're not over there downloading
remixes you fool Oh woof
thanks alright and as you can see from
this album cover we will be talking
about the new roots album how I got over
in case you don't know him the roots are
a hip hop band yes band and this is
their ninth studio LP now I know some of
y'all who are in my subscriber base
don't like hip-hop I don't know why but
if you were to try one contemporary
hip-hop act the roots are one of the few
groups I would highly highly recommend
not only for their live dynamic
instrumentation but for the really heavy
soul funk and jazz influences that just
pour out of their music something that a
lot of modern gangsta rap is completely
devoid of the band has had a lot of
lineup changes since their inception but
their core is still intact with
Questlove on drums their lead MC Black
Thought and Kamal on keyboards around
this simple skeleton some of this
group's best material has been written
and that is no less true for this album
right from the start of the track walk
alone the band builds a song out of some
really chunky drumbeats and somber piano
chords and from this come something
really really emotionally impacting this
song also hits a real homerun with the
chorus and most of the tracks do it
really avoids something that bugs me
with a lot of modern hip-hop music where
it'll try to pose a real attitude in the
verses and the rhymes but once the
chorus comes around it'll put some corny
overly sweet sing-songy voice in
the hook which really kind of turns me
off however the roots are very conscious
of that emotional balance on this LP and
make sure all the pieces to the puzzle
fit long story short
these songs are built solid brick house
and a lot of what makes the tracks on
this album stand out from one another
are the fantastic and well-thought-out
guest spots vocals from monsters of
Fulke
John Legend and even joanna newsom
brings some emotion to these tracks that
just could not have been there otherwise
with the girls from the Dirty Projectors
showing up on this thing - there is
quite a bit of indie star power
throughout this new route - album but
I'm very pleased to say that this thing
is not over shadowed by its guest
contributors even its guest MCS I'm no
roots expert I haven't heard all nine of
their studio albums and the ones that
I'm most familiar with are organics do
you want more Things Fall Apart and I've
been listening to a little bit of their
more recent material - but from what I
can gather this LP is one of the most
downtrodden sobering albums I have ever
heard much less ever heard from the
roots which is really funny because from
what I've read the band perceives this
to be an overly positive album a very
positive album I mean if this is
positivity I don't want to see
negativity but honestly it's not like
this album is suicidal it doesn't see
life as pointless it doesn't see life as
futile I guess the way I could put it
best is that this is the sound of being
fed up politics and social issues have
always played a huge part in the roots
music and that's also true on this album
and to be honest why wouldn't the roots
be fed up the world sucks right now war
oil leak racial injustice sexism
pollution poverty I mean I mean have you
looked outside black thought and guest
emcees like porn Fonte and blue paint a
rough but relatable sketch of the
political climate according to them and
to me it hit a really good balance
between being enjoyable
clever being well written and preaching
a little gospel - the way I see it it's
kind of like reporting feel free if you
want to disagree but this is the world
according to us it's really hard not to
feel the struggle that these MCS are in
the Rhymes and that just makes this
album so much more of a powerhouse my
one gripe and believe me it's just one I
really don't have much to say about this
album in the realm of negativity is that
the last two tracks just kind of feel
very out of place for me
kind of like bonus songs because they
really break the emotional narrative of
this album and they really break the
subject narrative of this album quite a
bit especially the track hustla which is
really kind of coming out of left field
which is why I understand them kind of
shoving it at the end of the album but
still I'm feeling an extremely extremely
strong eight on this album if not a
light nine if you guys are looking for
something from the adventurous side of
rap music something that has a real
political tinge to it it hits a lot of
groups and it's one of the best hip-hop
albums I've heard all year the roots how
I got over what do you guys think of it
tell me down there in the the comments
did you love this thing did you hate
this thing
and why anthony Fantan oh the roots how
I got over forever
